thread.title: Auburn 21, Prattville 17: Tigers upset Lions late
thread.title_full: Auburn 21, Prattville 17: Tigers upset Lions late

title: Auburn 21, Prattville 17: Tigers upset Lions late
text:
Auburn 21, Prattville 17: Tigers upset Lions late Kamarri Darrington Special to the Advertiser 11:08 p.m. CDT October 16, 2015 Prattville running back Kingston Davis is upended by Auburn defenders at Stanley-Jensen Stadium in Prattville on Friday. (Photo: Mickey Welsh/Advertiser) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PRATTVILLE — There was an uneasy feeling for the Prattville fans at Stanley-Jensen Stadium as the Lions couldn’t put Auburn away in the fourth quarter. 
After it was over, there was nothing but anger and frustration for the home team. 
Auburn receiver Patrick Anders caught a 46-yard touchdown pass from backup quarterback Brooks Fuller with 1:25 left to give the Tigers a 21-17 win over the Lions in a pivotal region game. 
Fuller completed 6 of 17 passes for 132 yards and an interception while filling in for injured started Bradley Northcutt. A 68-yard run by Tyus Flakes set up the game-winning score. 
“We’ve been through a lot of adversity this year,” Auburn head coach Adam Winegarden said. “We’ve been there supporting our kids through all of it. I’m just proud for them for showing so much fight tonight.” 
Winegarden said Fuller’s performance on the final drive was indicative of his work in practice. 
“Fuller played some last year and has some experience,” Winegarden said. “He’s done a good job preparing, and it took a lot of guts to complete that 2-minute drill.” 
Prattville (5-3, 2-3 Class 7A, Region 2) looked to have sealed the game when Austin Wilson intercepted Fuller at the Auburn 36 with 4:35 left and a 17-14 lead. 
Lions senior running back Kingston Davis, who finished with 127 yards and a touchdown on 31 carries, was stopped short on fourth-and-1 on the Auburn 27 with 2:30 left. 
Prattville head coach Chad Anderson said he elected to go for it because he thought trying a field goal wouldn’t help. 
“A first down would’ve allowed us to run some more clock,” Anderson said. “We wanted them to use their timeouts, so that was the call we made. We left a lot of points on the field tonight.” 
The Lions jumped out to a 10-0 lead, but three turnovers kept the Tigers (4-4, 3-2) close. Derek Gappa’s fumble with less than a minute to go ended the Lions’ final drive. 
Moore completed 12 of 18 passes for 114 yards and rushed for another 99 yards and a touchdown on seven carries. Wide receiver DeKeith Whatley caught six passes for 64 yards. 
Davis, one of 29 seniors who played their final home game on Friday, has now rushed for 1,320 yards this season. 
Lions senior linebacker Dytarious Johnson had 11 tackles. Jamal Taylor added 10 and Braxton James had eight. 
Auburn got some help from the football gods on its first-half scoring drive. 
Fuller fumbled near the goal line, but running back Cobi Smith picked it up and scored from 2 yards out with 1:27 left before halftime to make it a 10-7 game. 
Flakes finished with 76 yards on six carries for the Auburn. Linebacker TreShun Floyd had 11 tackles, and cornerback Damon Freeman finished with nine. 
Auburn will play at Smiths Station next Friday while Prattville faces a must-win game with Robert E. Lee. 
“This game was just as important as the Lee game will be,” Anderson said. “We have got a lot of issues we need to correct. We have to do a better job at execution.” Buy Photo Prattville quarterback Josh Moore carries against Auburn in Prattville, Ala. on Friday October 16, 2015. Mickey Welsh / Advertiser Fullscreen Buy Photo Prattville's Kingston Davis (20) carries against Auburn's Courtney Jimmerson (19) in Prattville, Ala. on Friday October 16, 2015.
